summary:
This specification defines an interoperable means for site developers to asynchronously transfer small HTTP data from the User Agent to a web server.

Initiated by the navigator.sendBeacon() method, the 'beacon' data will be transmitted by the User Agent as soon as possible, but independent of document navigation. The sendBeacon method returns true if the user agent is able to successfully queue the data for transfer. Otherwise it returns false.
visibility: Covered as part of a larger article but not on its own
name: Beacon

summary:
The latest draft of the CSS OM spec changed the type for a number of Element and HTMLElement properties from long to float. 

Specifically the following properties:
Element::clientHeight
Element::clientWidth
Element::clientLeft
Element::clientTop
Element::scrollTop
Element::scrollLeft
Element::scrollWidth
Element::scrollHeight
HTMLElement::offsetWidth
HTMLElement::offsetHeight
HTMLElement::offsetTop
HTMLElement::offsetLeft
visibility: Covered as part of a larger article but not on its own
name: Subpixel precision for clientWidth, offsetWidth, scrollTop, et al

comments: MDN entry for sendBeacon(), https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/navigator.sendBeacon
summary:
Asynchronous to document navigation, transfer smaller payloads from the User Agent. Initiated by the navigator.sendBeacon() method, the 'beacon' data will be transmitted by the User Agent as soon as possible, but independent of document navigation. The sendBeacon() method only returns a flag indicating if the User Agent will send the data.

It aims to support web content needing to flush page state when the document is unloaded.
visibility: Only a very small number of web developers will care about
name: navigator.sendBeacon

comments: Lots of discussion on Intent to Remove thread: https://groups.google.com/a/chromium.org/forum/#!topic/blink-dev/xh9fPX0ijqk
summary:
The global showModalDialog() method displays a modal dialog box containing a specified HTML document. This feature has an incredibly high cost in terms of code complexity since it requires us to run an event loop on top of an arbitrary JavaScript stack.  It also complicates the web platform by making task dispatch reentrant and hard to reason about. We will be removing support in Chrome 36.

Details: http://dev.opera.com/blog/showmodaldialog/
visibility: Will this feature generate articles on sites like html5rocks.com
name: showModalDialog

summary:
Shadow DOM was enabled in M25 but the spec has gone through quite a few changes since then. This entry is for tracking these changes.

About Shadow DOM: enables DOM tree encapsulation. Without it, widgets may inadvertently break pages by using conflicting CSS selectors, class or id names, or JavaScript variables.

WOFF 2.0 significantly improves font compression. We are seeing average gains of 24% with peaks above 50% in particular for the larger fonts such as those typically used by CJK languages (analysis ran on the whole Google Fonts corpus).


M33: switching to Brotli Compression Algorithm (instead of LZMA).
M35: sent web facing change PSA prior to enabling by default.
